comment_text: Glad you shared this Tim, been watching you for a fair while now from the UK and like you, I love everything Space related. Keep up the great work.

Tim once you calm down take a look at the drone video of the test. It's interesting to me how the rocket exhaust begins its flight and also again ends its flight a bright orange/yellow and the transitional stage of the flight the flame looks clean. I would have to guess they deliberately run a rich burn to prevent scorching the pad and run it lean and clean to cruise, then run a rich burn again when approaching the landing pad- and the rich exhaust also creates the massive plumes of smoke we don't really see being formed when flying the transition. Is this theory of mine true? Or can you find out?

Seeing this kind of progress for something that could be really meaningful for our species is quite something. What I tell those who don't see the big deal is that this is the start (well not quite if you consider F9 reusability to be the start) of humanity being able to explore the solar system without requiring insane amounts of money.

That was pretty cool. Wonder what flew off? Interesting to see where this might go in the future. Not sure of the application just yet.  Not sure about Mars...lot of issues there. But the moon might be a possibility since this is large and would provide a good medium term stay on the Moon or could be used to haul cargo to the moon such as a number of inflatable habitats, vehicles, solar panels, nuclear generators, etc. I know Musk also wants to use this for long distance flight too....from US to Japan for example. This is a good start but think it will be a decade before implementation.
